title: 112_hr5964
content: The "Cross-Border Trade Enhancement Act of 2012" defines key terms such as Administrator, Person, and Secretary. It also grants authority to enter agreements for certain services at land border ports of entry. The "Cross-Border Trade Enhancement Act of 2012" grants the Secretary authority to enter agreements with persons for customs and immigration services at land border ports of entry, with fees to reimburse costs incurred by U.S. Customs and Border Protection. The Secretary can impose a fee on individuals requesting customs and immigration services at land border ports of entry to reimburse U.S. Customs and Border Protection for costs incurred, including salaries, expenses, and other related expenses. The U.S. Customs and Border Protection can terminate services for individuals who fail to pay fees imposed by the Secretary in a timely manner. Fees collected are credited to offset expenses and can only be used for Customs and Border Protection expenditures. The fees collected by U.S. Customs and Border Protection can only be used to pay for services provided under agreements and remain available for expenditure without a fiscal year limitation. SEC. 4. EVALUATION OF ALTERNATIVE FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS FOR CONSTRUCTION AND MAINTENANCE OF INFRASTRUCTURE AT LAND BORDER PORTS OF ENTRY. The Administrator must establish procedures within 180 days of the Act's enactment for evaluating proposals to enter cost-sharing agreements or provide gifts for infrastructure at land border ports of entry. The procedures must include specific requirements and timelines for proposal review. The Administrator must evaluate proposals for infrastructure at land border ports of entry, considering the impact on reducing wait times at the port and other entry points. If a proposal is not approved, the person who submitted it will be notified of the reasons for the decision. The Administrator evaluates proposals for infrastructure at land border ports of entry based on the potential to increase trade and travel efficiency, enhance security, and reduce wait times. If a proposal is not approved, the submitter will be informed of the reasons for the decision.
